You have it right. Programmer Tests (your "u=
nit tests") play an entirely different role than Integration Tests. The goa=
l of Programmer Tests is to ensure that object-level behavior is correct (a=
s expected), but may not guarantee correct collaboration among objects. Tha=
t's why we have Customer Tests and Integration Tests.

Customer Tests allow=
 us to be confident that we're building the right features.

Programmer Tes=
ts allow us to be confident that our objects do what we think we asked them=
 to do.

Integration Tests allow us to be confident that our objects play n=
icely with one another. Integration Tests are often headless (UI-less) Cust=
omer Tests.

Programmer Tests run faster than Integration Tests, so we run =
them more often. That's one of their biggest benefits.
